p: Calcaneal distal tuber length (DstL) was negatively related to Greenland temperature (slope: −0.45 mm/°C ± 0.11; z = −3.95 p < .001) with intercepts at 78 ± 4 mm for B. bison, 90 ± 3 mm for B. antiquus, and 87 ± 2 mm for B. occidentalis. The relationship between calcaneal distal tuber length (DstL) and relative global temperature was −1.77 mm/°C ± 0.45 ( z = −3.95, p < .001) with intercepts at 92 ± 2 mm for B. bison, 103 ± 3 mm for B. antiquus, and 101 ± 2 mm for B. occidentalis. Consequently, the slope of estimated body mass with global temperature was also negative at −41 kg/°C (± 10; z = −4.10, p < .001) with intercepts at 521 ± 36 kg for B. bison, 737 ± 45 kg for B. antiquus, and 676 ± 36 kg for B. occidentalis (Figure 6). This relationship predicts that B. bison will decrease by 164 ± 40 kg to 357 ± 54 kg if global temperature rises from 0°C to +4°C (Figure 6).
